frameDefinitions: This frame concerns an Evaluee being judged for its quality, i.e. how much it would probably be liked.
These words describe how outgoing or sociable a Protagonist is judged to be by a (usually implicit)
A Speaker addresses an Addressee with a Message, which may be indirectly referred to as a Topic.
An Entity stands out perceptually in comparison to other members of its type.
This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication.
The words in this frame describe an Experiencer's emotions with respect to some Content.
frameExamples: He was <t>shy</t> with strangers and afraid of showing his feelings.
Pilot Mountain in NC is very <t>prominent</t>.
Evelyn was <t>candid</t> with me about the party.
My <t>enjoyment</t> of the movie was considerably impaired by the seven-foot guy sitting in front of me.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Evaluee</fen> is being judged for its quality.
This role marks expressions that denote a scalar property of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> with respect to which the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is judged.
The Protagonist is the person whose sociability is being described.
The Protagonist may be sociable, shy, outgoing, etc. when with particular Company (specific people or types of people).  Company usually occurs in a PP Complement with a target adjective:
The Protagonist may be sociable, shy, outgoing, etc. when in a particular situation, or about performing some action.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen>.
The <fen>Addressee</fen> receives the <fen>Message</fen> from the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the communication produced by the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is a general description of the content of the <fen>Message</fen>.
This role is the <fen>Medium</fen> in which the <fen>Message</fen> is expressed.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> informs the <fen>Addressee</fen> of the <fen>Message</fen>.
<fen>Place</fen> is the location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen> informs  the <fen>Addressee</fen> of the <fen>Message</fen>.
The <fen>Entity</fen> for which the saliency <fen>Attribute</fen> is appropriate and under consideration.
The feature of the <fen>Entity</fen> which is under discussion, namely perceptual salience.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Entity</fen> is in the state of having  a particular salience.
This role refers to the location where the <fen>Entity</fen> has a prominence of some <fen>Attribute</fen>.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses.

<fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This role does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> role in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about'.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> experiences the emotion or other internal state.

<fen>Content</fen> is what the <fen>Experiencer</fen>'s feelings or experiences are directed towards or based upon.  The <fen>Content</fen> differs from a stimulus because the <fen>Content</fen> is not construed as being direcly responsible for causing the emotion.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflect his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the area about which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has the particular experience.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
The time at which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is in the specified emotional state.
listRoleExamples: He gave me another lame <fex>excuse</fex>.
The Beaujolais Nouveau is dazzling <fex>in freshness</fex>.
<fex>Pat</fex> is sociable.
Kim is shy <fex>of strangers</fex>.
Kim is outgoing <fex>when traveling alone</fex>.
<fex>Bill</fex> told me that he would come to the party.
The authorities informed me <fex>that my brother had been arrested</fex>.
Leroy told his mother <fex>about his arrest</fex>.

Even when we had a size problem they informed me <fex>right away</fex> and everything worked
out great.
She looked at it for a few moments, thinking of Mark Smeaton and what he had told her <fex>on the steps of City Hall</fex>.
If you are asked to search for the plus sign with red-vertical and green-horizontal elements, <fex>all the red and green plus signs</fex> may seem to become salient.
The diagram, (a frequency distribution chart) shows a <fex>prominently</fex> conspicuous region of stars that extend from the extremely bright and hot stars to the faint and cool variety.
The affection for American culture seemed more prominent <fex>last year</fex>.
<fex>Evelyn</fex> was candid about the party.
Evelyn made some candid <fex>remarks</fex>.
Evelyn was candid <fex>about the party</fex>.
Evelyn made some candid remarks <fex>in French</fex>.
Everyone loves <fex>compliments</fex>.
The delight <fex>on her face</fex> was mixed with asonishment.
Mr. Whiskers was upset <fex>about his cat treats</fex>.
Tracy was in an irritated <fex>mood</fex>.
It felt pretty awkward to partake in such a nervous <fex>ceremony</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex>, Bob was still interested in the young Republicans.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: more than a couple of years
